column1: Core terms (full form first)
- RACI — Responsible
- Responsible: person(s) who do the work.
- Accountable: person who owns the outcome (only one).
- Consulted: people who provide input (two-way).
- Informed: people who are kept up to date (one-way).
- RAID — Risks
- Risks: uncertain events that may affect objectives (with mitigation).
- Assumptions: things the project team accepts as true for planning.
- Issues: current problems that require action.
- Decisions: formal choices made
- BIA — Business Impact Analysis
- Analysis to identify and prioritise critical functions and the impact of their loss.
- RTO — Recovery Time Objective
- Maximum acceptable time to restore a service after an outage.
- RPO — Recovery Point Objective
- Maximum acceptable amount of data loss
What is a risk? (short)
- A risk is a possible future event that could affect your project's objectives (positive or negative). In this project we focus on negative risks (threats) that need mitigation.
Likelihood vs Impact
- Likelihood (1–5): How probable is the risk? 1 = Very unlikely
- Impact (1–5): If the risk occurs
column2: how severe is the effect on objectives? 1 = Negligible

column1: - Score = Likelihood × Impact (range 1–25). Use Score to prioritise.
Priority bands (example)
- 7–12: Medium
- 19–25: Critical
Residual risk
- Residual risk = remaining risk after mitigation. Track both initial and residual Likelihood/Impact if you apply mitigations.

column1: Simple scoring logic (do this in a cell or script)
- Score = Likelihood * Impact
- Priority = map Score to band above (Low/Medium/High/Critical)
- Optionally compute ResidualScore if you reduce Likelihood/Impact after mitigations
Quick visual idea (heatmap)
- Create a 5×5 grid with Impact on X and Likelihood on Y. Cell color = number of risks or average Score. Use conditional formatting (Sheets/Excel) or matrix visual (Power BI).
RAID vs. Risk register
- Keep a single RAID log when convenient and use the Type column to filter (Risk / Assumption / Issue / Decision). For interview / portfolio

column1: Tips for beginners
- Keep entries simple and concrete — 1–2 sentences. Recruiters prefer clarity over jargon.
- Focus on ownership: always assign an Owner even if it's "You (Project Lead)".
- Track Status: Open / In Progress / Mitigated / Closed. This shows progress.
- Commit early and often — daily commits are great for your Day1-30 project.
